title: Field Methods in Hydrogeology
description: A course dealing with the theory and applications of field techniques in hydrology. Physical, chemical, and isotopic methods are included with applications to groundwater and surface water hydrology. The course will consist of lectures, field activities, projects and assignments. All will be conducted over a 3-week time period at the end of the Winter term in April. Students without the required prerequisite may seek consent of the instructor.
requirementsDescription: Prereq: EARTH 458 or 650 and consent of Instructor

title: Special Studies for MSc Students
description: Course credit may be given for special studies related to the research interest of a student and a member of the faculty by special arrangement.

title: Special Studies for PhD Students
description: Course credit may be given for special studies related to the research interest of a student and a member of the faculty by special arrangement.

title: Introductory Earth Sciences
description: This course explores the geological processes of the Earth's interior and surface. These include volcanism, earthquakes, mountain building, glaciation and weathering. Students will gain an appreciation of how these processes have controlled the evolution of our planet and the role of geology in meeting society's current and future demand for sustainable energy and mineral resources.   [Note: EARTH 121L is recommended. Offered: F]

title: Geochemistry 1
description: Origin, abundance, and geochemistry of elements. Introduction to stable isotope geology and radiometric dating. Basic aqueous geochemistry. [Offered: W,S]
requirementsDescription: Prereq: CHEM 123, 125 or level at least 2A Geological Engineering

title: Petrography
description: An introduction to optical mineralogy. Basic theory of the behaviour of light through minerals; concept of indicatrices; understanding relief, retardation, birefringence, interference figures and other optical properties of minerals. Microscopic examination of important rock forming minerals and the identification of igneous, metamorphic, and sedimentary rocks. Introduction to silicate phase equilibria; use of mineral stability diagrams to understand igneous and metamorphic petrogenesis. [Offered: W,S]

title: Thesis Proposal
description: The first term of a potential two-term supervised research project in which students prepare a research proposal and conduct research. Students will present their research proposal in an oral presentation and written report. [Note: In order to progress to a two-term project via EARTH 436B, a grade of 75% must be achieved in this course; Offered: F, S]
requirementsDescription: Prereq: Level at least 4A; Honours Earth Sciences, Environmental Science - Geoscience Specialization, and Geochemistry students

title: Honours Thesis
description: An optional second term of a two-term supervised research project in which students learn to gather and interpret data. Students will present their findings in a formal presentation and written thesis. [Offered: W]
requirementsDescription: Prereq: EARTH 436A with a grade of at least 75%

title: Physical Hydrogeology
description: An introduction to physical hydrogeology, including Darcy's law, the groundwater flow equations for steady-state and transient conditions, applications to flow nets, aquifer testing, groundwater resources, and groundwater protection. The role of groundwater in the hydrologic cycle is explored with emphasis on natural groundwater flow systems and their influence on stream flow. Physical processes controlling groundwater contamination are introduced. [Note:  EARTH 123 is recommended as a prerequisite. Offered: F,S]
requirementsDescription: Prereq: One of EARTH (121 and 121L), (122 and 122L), CIVE 153, ENVE 153, GEOE 153

title: Earth Engineering
description: This course studies earth materials and processes from an engineering point of view through case histories and problem sets. The course develops a geological knowledge for applications to any physical environment and provides an appreciation of the impact of engineering work on the environment. Topics include mineral and rock identification, the rock cycle, structural geology and tectonics, geology of Canada, effects of water, ice and wind. Students are also introduced to the concept of geologic time, topographic and geologic maps, and the basic principles and tools used to determine geologic history. [Offered as: CIVE 153 (W), EARTH 153 (S), ENVE 153 (S), GEOE 153 (S)]

title: Field Methods in Hydrogeology
description: This course exposes students to a wide variety of field and laboratory techniques for collecting hydrogeologic data and to gain experience in interpreting the data.  Advantages and limitations of various measurement and data reduction techniques for evaluating groundwater flow systems are demonstrated in a set of field exercises carried out at the groundwater demonstration facility located on the university North Campus.  These exercises illustrate the complexity of natural systems and the need for good data collection and interpretation skills when characterizing such systems . [Offered: F,S]

title: Earth MSc Seminar Proposal
description: A written research proposal, and a seminar and defence of the proposal to be given by all MSc students (thesis option) within two terms of entering this program.
